'''''Leucocoprinus birnbaumii''''' is a [[species]] of [[gilled mushroom]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Agaricaceae]]. It is common in the tropics and subtropics, but in temperate regions frequently occurs in [[greenhouses]] and flowerpots, hence its common names of '''flowerpot parasol''' and '''plantpot dapperling'''. [[Basidiocarps|The fruit body]]   is mildly [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]], if consumed in large quantities.

{{mycomorphbox

==Taxonomy==
The species was first published as ''Agaricus luteus'' by the [[English people|English]] [[mycologist]] [[James Bolton]] who described and illustrated it from a hothouse near [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] in 1785.<ref name = Bolton/> Unfortunately, the name ''A. luteus'' had already been published for a different fungus, making Bolton's ''A. luteus'' illegitimate. Nonetheless, many popular North American books continued to use the name '''''Lepiota lutea''''' until the 1980s.<ref name="Arora"/><ref name=Lincoff1981/> In 1839 Czech mycologist [[August Carl Joseph Corda|August Corda]] described the same species from [[Prague]] where it was found growing in a greenhouse by a garden inspector named Birnbaum, hence the [[specific name (botany)|epithet]] ''birnbaumii''.<ref name = Roberts&Evans/>

===English names===
In the UK, ''Leucocoprinus birnbaumii'' has been given the recommended [[common name]] of "plantpot dapperling".<ref name = Holden/> In North America, it has also been called the "yellow parasol",<ref name="Arora"/> "flowerpot parasol",<ref name="Arora"/> "yellow houseplant mushroom",<ref name="Volk"/> "lemon-yellow lepiota",<ref name=Lincoff1981/> or "yellow pleated parasol".<ref name=McKnight1987/>

==Description==
Fruit bodies of ''Leucocoprinus birnbaumii'' are [[agaric]]oid (mushroom-shaped) and occur singly or in small clumps. All parts are bright, pale sulphur-yellow, but fade with age. When young, the [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is usually taller than broad, later becoming convex and around 20–60 mm (1–2.5 in) across. The cap surface is smooth but dotted with fine, easily detached scales, and often develops shallow, radial grooves near the margin. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are free (not attached to the stem) and are covered by a [[partial veil]] when young, which ruptures to leave a fragile, evanescent [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] on the [[stipe (mycology)|stem]]. Microscopically, the species is distinguished by its thick-walled, ellipsoid [[spore]]s that are [[dextrinoid]], have a [[germ pore]], and measure around 8–12 by 5–9 μm.<ref name = Vellinga2001/>
[[File:Flowerpot parasol.JPG|thumbnail|A single fruit body of ''L. birnbaumii'']]

===Similar species===
''Leucocoprinus straminellus'' is a similar, slightly paler (sometimes entirely whitish) species that may also occasionally appear in hothouses and plantpots in temperate regions. It is best distinguished microscopically by its smaller spores that lack a germ pore.<ref name = Vellinga2001/> ''Leucocoprinus flavescens'', described from North America, is also small-spored and has a yellowish cap with a brownish centre.<ref name=KuoA/> ''Leucocoprinus sulphurellus'' is a yellow species that occurs in the Caribbean area, but has gills that bruise bright blue-green.<ref name = Roberts&Evans/>

==Habitat and distribution==
Like all ''[[Leucocoprinus]]'' species, ''L. birnbaumii'' is a [[saprotroph]], living on very decayed plant matter (humus or compost). The fungus is common throughout the [[tropics]] and [[subtropic]]s, extending into warmer parts of the [[temperate]] zones. Rarely, it appears in cooler areas, fruit bodies having been recorded as far north as England,<ref name = CBIB/> but these seem to be temporary introductions. In these areas (such as North America, Europe, and Australia) it is more usually found in hothouses and plant pots than in the wild.<ref name="Volk"/><ref name=KuoB/>

==Chemistry==
Fruit bodies of ''Leucocoprinus birnbaumii'' are poisonous if consumed, causing significant stomach problems.<ref name = Hall/>

The yellow color of the mushrooms is from [[alkaloids]] known as [[birnbaumins]];<ref name="Bartsch"/> whether these compounds are responsible for the mushroom's toxicity is unknown.
{{-}}
